alert.note: Alert for Tuscarawas (Ohio) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Pittsburgh (Western Pennsylvania and East Central Ohio)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued August 24 at 3:56PM EDT until August 27 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Pittsburgh PA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Ohio... Stillwater Creek At Uhrichsville affecting Tuscarawas County. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY MORNING TO SUNDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Stillwater Creek at Uhrichsville. * WHEN...From Friday morning to Sunday evening. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Stillwater Creek comes out of its banks in several locations resulting in overflowing in poor drainage areas. Minor flooding of low lying areas begins. At 11.5 feet, Flood waters of Stillwater Creek will reach the intersection of East 12th Street and North Main Street in Uhrichsville and approach Newport Street. Little Stillwater Creek will flood most of Phac Park along with portions of Wilson Road in Dennison. At 12.9 feet, Numerous low land areas are flooded. Stillwater Creek begins to flood portions of Newport Street in Uhrichsville. Homes along Park Drive begin to flood. Sections of Wilson Road near Phac Park are flooded. At 13.3 feet, Flood waters reach Newport Avenue in Uhrichsville as well as East 12th Street and North Main Street half way to East 11th Street. Phac Park along Little Stillwater Creek in Dennison is flooded. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 5.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late tomorrow morning to a crest of 11.7 feet early Saturday morning. It will then fall below flood stage early Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 11.1 feet on 11/13/2022. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at weather.gov/pbz.
